title: 111_hr3834
content: The "Green Energy Investment Zone Act of 2009" increases incentives for alternative energy properties in high job-loss areas. The Green Energy Investment Zone Act of 2009 enhances tax credits for energy property in high job-loss zones, increasing the credit from 30% to 40% and from 10% to 20%. The Green Energy Investment Zone Act of 2009 defines a green energy investment zone as an eligible city in a high job-loss metropolitan or micropolitan statistical area with a population of at least 50,000. The term 'eligible city' in a micropolitan statistical area refers to a city with a population of at least 10,000 based on the 2000 census. 'High-job loss' in this context means an area designated by the Secretary as among the lowest third in terms of job losses. The term 'eligible city' in a micropolitan statistical area refers to a city with a population of at least 10,000 based on the 2000 census. Areas designated as among the lowest third in terms of economic conditions, residential economic well-being factors, and changes from 1990 to 2000 are considered for comparison. The curr_chunk discusses economic conditions related to growth in employment, annual payroll, and business establishments in relation to gross metropolitan product per job or gross micropolitan product per job. Residential economic well-being factors are also considered. The curr_chunk discusses factors related to residential economic well-being, including per capita income, median household income, poverty rate, unemployment rate, and labor force participation rate. Additionally, there is a special rule for facilities located in high job-loss zones regarding qualified investment credit facilities placed in service in green energy investment zones. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to the tax code related to renewable energy production, including increasing the percentage for electricity produced from certain renewable resources. Additionally, a special rule is introduced for facilities located in high job-loss zones, providing an increase in the amount for qualified facilities placed in service in these areas. The curr_chunk discusses amendments to the tax code for specified energy property, including a special rule for facilities in high job-loss zones, increasing the percentage for qualified facilities in green energy investment zones. The tax code amendments include increasing the limit for nonbusiness energy property and residential energy efficient property, with a special rule for green energy investment zones. The tax code is amended to increase the limit for nonbusiness energy property and residential energy efficient property, with a special rule for green energy investment zones. The amendment also includes a substitution of '40 percent' for '30 percent' in certain cases and an increase in the limitation for qualifying advanced energy projects. The amendments made by this section, including an increase in limitations for nonbusiness energy property and residential energy efficient property, will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. The increased limitations will apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008.
